Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Networking Technology and Systems Early-Career Investigators (NeTS-ECI) Workshop is aimed at developing the early-career NeTS research community to address emerging challenges and pursue promising research opportunities in the domain of computer and information networking. NeTS-ECI provides an opportunity for early-career researchers to engage in discussions with peers to share perspectives and explore new research frontiers.

Each workshop participant will also have an opportunity to showcase his/her research interests, build a collaborator network, kick-start collaborations, and benefit from professional development activities. These activities include presentations about the NSF merit review process and elements of successful NSF proposals, talks from leaders in networking on how to build successful large research programs, and how to identify and work on strong research collaborations. This workshop will thus play an important role in fostering a strong community of early career researchers in NeTS. The output of the workshop will be a detailed reporting outlining the various presentations and breakout discussions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the organization of the the 2017 edition of the NeTS early career workshop (https://sites.google.com/view/netsearlycareer2017) on July 31 and August 1 in Arlington VA. This workshop is dedicated to developing the early­career NeTS research community to address emerging challenges and pursue promising research opportunities in the domain of computer and information networking. It has provided an opportunity for participants to engage in discussions with peers to share perspectives and explore new research frontiers, to obtain career advice from senior members of NeTS community, to showcase his/her research interests, to build a collaborator network, to kick­start collaborations, and to benefit from professional development activities such as presentations on the NSF merit review process and elements of successful NSF proposals.

The workshop featured 11 TPC members, 5 plenary speakers, and 7 mentors as below:

========
Program Committee:

Ethan Katz­Bassett, USC Nate Foster, Cornell Shyam Gollakota, U Washington Y. Charlie Hu, Purdue Dina Papagiannaki, Google Lili Qiu, UT Austin Vyas Sekar (chair), CMU Xinyu Zhang, UW­Madison Ben Y. Zhao, UCSBLin Zhong, Rice Xia Zhou (chair), Dartmouth

Plenary speakers:

Romit Roy Choudhury, UIUC; Jim Kurose, NSF; Darleen Fisher/Thyaga Nandagopal, NSF; Ashutosh Sabharwal, Rice; Srinivasan Seshan, CMU

Mentors:

Nick Feamster, Princeton; Sachin Katti, Stanford; Robin Kravets, UIUC; Ashutosh Sabharwal, Rice; Alex Snoeren, UCSD; Geoff Voelker, UCSD; Ellen Zegura, Georgia Tech

========

63 participants (15 female) attended the workshop, among which 35 are junior faculty, 22 are senior PhD students, and 6 are post­docs. They are all from US­based institutions.After the workshop, 52 participants responded to our survey. When asked to rate how satisfied they are with the event using the scale from 1 (not very) to 5 (very much), 46.2% responded with 5 and 48.1% responded with 4, and 5.8% responded with 3. It indicated that the majority of participants have found the workshop helpful and beneficial to their careers.
